[File: aptos-core/types/src/keyless/openid_sig.rs] [Function: verify_jwt_signature()] [Expiration Check Bypass] Does verify_signature_without_exp_check at line 137 properly validate JWT expiration despite the function name, or is this check entirely skipped creating a vulnerability? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/keyless/openid_sig.rs] [Function: verify_jwt_signature()] [Padding Oracle] Can differences in error messages from RSA verification leak information about the signature validity through timing or error analysis? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/keyless/openid_sig.rs] [Struct: OpenIdSig] [Memory Exhaustion] Can an attacker provide extremely large jwt_sig or epk_blinder vectors at lines 25 and 32, causing memory exhaustion DoS when deserializing OpenIdSig? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/keyless/openid_sig.rs] [Struct: OpenIdSig] [JSON Injection] Can the jwt_payload_json string field at line 27 contain malicious JSON that exploits parser vulnerabilities when deserialized in verify_jwt_claims? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/keyless/openid_sig.rs] [Struct: OpenIdSig] [UID Key Manipulation] Can an attacker provide arbitrary uid_key values at line 29 that extract unintended claims or bypass verification logic in get_uid_val? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/keyless/openid_sig.rs] [Struct: OpenIdSig] [Blinder Size Attack] Does the EPK_BLINDER_NUM_BYTES constant at line 43 properly constrain epk_blinder length, or can attackers provide shorter/longer blinders causing hash computation errors? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/keyless/openid_sig.rs] [Struct: OpenIdSig] [Pepper Manipulation] Can the pepper field at line 34 be manipulated to generate identity commitments that collide with existing accounts, enabling account takeover? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/keyless/openid_sig.rs] [Struct: OpenIdSig] [Optional Field Exploit] Can the optional idc_aud_val at line 37 be None when it should be Some, or vice versa, bypassing audience validation checks? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/keyless/openid_sig.rs] [Function: try_from()] [BCS Deserialization] Can the bcs::from_bytes deserialization at line 166 be exploited with malformed BCS data causing panics, memory corruption, or bypassing validation? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/keyless/openid_sig.rs] [Function: try_from()] [Error Handling] Does the generic CryptoMaterialError at line 166 hide specific deserialization failures that could indicate attacks or data corruption? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/keyless/openid_sig.rs] [Function: get_uid_val()] [Email Verification Bypass] Can an attacker bypass the email_verified check at lines 196-207 by providing email_verified as a non-boolean, non-string type that unwrap_or defaults allow through? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/keyless/openid_sig.rs] [Function: get_uid_val()] [String Case Sensitivity] Can the string comparison at line 205 be bypassed with case variations of 'true' (True, TRUE, TrUe) that pass as valid email verification? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/keyless/openid_sig.rs] [Function: get_uid_val()] [Boolean Coercion] Does the email_verified_as_bool logic at line 202 properly handle all JSON boolean representations, or can string-to-boolean coercion be exploited? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/keyless/openid_sig.rs] [Function: get_uid_val()] [Missing Field Attack] Can the email or email_verified fields be missing causing context() to fail at lines 196-200, but be bypassed through additional_claims fallback? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/keyless/openid_sig.rs] [Function: get_uid_val()] [Type Confusion] Can additional_claims at lines 215-221 contain non-string values that pass as_str() checks but cause incorrect uid_val extraction? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/keyless/openid_sig.rs] [Function: get_uid_val()] [UID Key Injection] Can a malicious uid_key like '../email' or 'email\x00verified' exploit the BTreeMap lookup at line 216 to access unintended claims? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/keyless/openid_sig.rs] [Function: get_uid_val()] [Sub Claim Override] Can an attacker use uid_key='sub' to bypass email verification requirements when the 'sub' claim should not be allowed for certain OIDC providers? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/keyless/openid_sig.rs] [Function: get_uid_val()] [Clone Performance] Do the .clone() operations at lines 199, 209, 213 create performance vulnerabilities when handling large claim values enabling resource exhaustion? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/keyless/openid_sig.rs] [Constant: EPK_BLINDER_NUM_BYTES] [Size Mismatch] Can the BYTES_PACKED_PER_SCALAR constant at line 43 mismatch with actual blinder sizes provided, causing pack_bytes_to_one_scalar to fail or produce incorrect hashes? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/keyless/openid_sig.rs] [Function: verify_jwt_claims()] [IDC Preimage Attack] Can an attacker find different (pepper, aud, uid_key, uid_val) tuples that produce the same IdCommitment at line 104, enabling identity theft? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/keyless/openid_sig.rs] [Function: reconstruct_oauth_nonce()] [Scalar Field Weakness] Does the BN254 scalar field size limit the security of nonce commitments, allowing birthday attacks below expected 128-bit security? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/keyless/openid_sig.rs] [Function: verify_jwt_claims()] [Poseidon Sponge] Can the Poseidon hash state be manipulated through carefully crafted input sequences at line 157 to produce predictable or colliding outputs? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/keyless/openid_sig.rs] [Function: reconstruct_oauth_nonce()] [EPK Length Attack] Can attackers provide ephemeral public keys larger than max_commited_epk_bytes causing truncation or padding errors in scalar packing at lines 147-150? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/keyless/openid_sig.rs] [Function: verify_jwt_claims()] [Timestamp Wraparound] Can the seconds_from_epoch function at lines 64-73 handle timestamps beyond 2038 or Unix epoch wraparound, or will it cause overflow errors? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/keyless/openid_sig.rs] [Function: verify_jwt_claims()] [Configuration Manipulation] Can an attacker exploit on-chain governance to modify max_exp_horizon_secs in Configuration, extending key validity windows beyond safe limits? (High)
